Introduction

If $p(x)$ is a polynomial of degree $n$, $$\begin{equation}p(x) = c_{0} + c_{1}x + c_{2}x^{2}+\cdots+c_{n}x^{n} \tag{1}\end{equation}$$ differentiating it successfully $n$ times, we get $$ \begin{alignat}{3} p’(x) = c_{1}+2 \cdot c_{2}x+\cdots+n \cdot c_{n}x^{(n+1)} \ p’’(x) = 2 \cdot c_{2}+ 2 \cdot 3 \cdot c_{3}x +\cdots+ (n - 1) \cdot n \cdot c_{n}x^{(n+2)} \ \vdots \ p^{(n)}(x) = 1 \cdot 2 \cdot 3 \cdots n \cdot c_{n} \end{alignat} $$

setting $x = 0$ in above equations, we get $$ c_{0}= p(0), \quad c_{1} = \frac{p’(0)}{1!}, \quad c_{2} = \frac{p’’(0)}{2!}, \quad \cdots \quad c_{n} = \frac{p^{(n)}(0)}{n!} $$ putting these calculated coefficient in equation $1$, we get $$ \tag{2} p(x) = p(0) + \frac{p’(0)}{2!}x^{2} + \frac{p’’(0)}{3!}x^{3} + \cdots + \frac{p^{(n)}(0)}{n!}x^{n} $$

Equation $2$ is called Maclaurin’s formula.

Instead of expanding equation as power of $x$ in equation $1$, we can expand the equation with respect to power of $x - a$ where $a$ is a constant value.

$$ \tag{3} p(x) = c_{0} + c_{1}(x - a) + c_{2}(x - a)^{2}+\cdots+c_{n}(x - a)^{n} $$ differentiating it successfully $n$ times, we get $$ \begin{alignat}{3} p’(x) = c_{1}+2 \cdot c_{2}(x - a)+\cdots+n \cdot c_{n}(x - a)^{(n+1)} \ p’’(x) = 2 \cdot c_{2}+ 2 \cdot 3 \cdot c_{3}(x - a) +\cdots+ (n - 1) \cdot n \cdot c_{n}(x - a)^{(n+2)} \ \vdots \ p^{(n)}(x) = 1 \cdot 2 \cdot 3 \cdots n \cdot c_{n} \end{alignat} $$ setting $x = a$ in above equations, we get $$ c_{0}= p(a), \quad c_{1} = \frac{p’(a)}{1!}, \quad c_{2} = \frac{p’’(a)}{2!}, \quad \cdots \quad c_{n} = \frac{p^{(n)}(a)}{n!} $$ putting these calculated coefficient in equation $3$, we get $$ \tag{4} p(x) = p(0) + \frac{p’(a)}{2!}(x - a)^{2} + \frac{p’’(a)}{3!}(x - a)^{3} + \cdots + \frac{p^{(n)}(a)}{n!}(x - a)^{n} $$

^fd3286

Equation $4$ is called Taylor’s formula.

Expansion of arbitrary function

Let $f(x)$ is a function defined on an interval $X$ that has derivate of all order upto $n \in \mathbb{N}$ at point $a$. ^cc2d81

  • More precisely, we need derivate of all order upto $n - 1$.
    • need more clarification (@2024-01-22)

Using [[#^fd3286| Taylor Theorem]], we can construct a polynomial of degree $n$, $$ p_{n}(x) = f(a) + \frac{1}{1!} f’(a) (x - a) + \frac{1}{2!} f’’(a) (x - a)^{2}+ \cdots + \frac{1}{n!} f(a)^{n} (x - a)^{n} \tag{5} $$ Since, $f(x)$ is not a polynomial, so $f(x) \ne p_{n}(x)$ . Let $r_{n}(x)$ , called the remainder term, represent difference between $f(x)$ and $p_{n}(x)$ for $x$ in the range $X$. $$ r_{n}(x) = f(x) - p_{n}(x) \tag{6} $$ $$ \begin{equation} r_{n}(x) = f(x) - f(a) - \frac{1}{1!} f’(a) (x - a) - \frac{1}{2!} f’’(a) (x - a)^{2}- \cdots - \frac{1}{n!} f^{(n)}(a) (x - a)^{n} \tag{7} \end{equation} $$

^901ba0

To investigate more about $r_{n}(x)$ , we can impose additional constraint that $f(x)$ must have $(n + 1)^{th}$ derivative in range $X$.

Replacing constant $a$ in equation 7 by a variable $z \in [a, x]$, we get a auxiliary function $$ \varphi(z) = f(x) - f(z) - \frac{1}{1!} f’(z) (x - z) - \frac{1}{2!} f’’(z) (x - z)^{2}- \cdots - \frac{1}{n!} f^{(n)}(z) (x - z)^{n} \tag{8} $$

^4a94db

It is obvious that $\varphi(z)$ is continuous and take following value on interval $X$. $$ \varphi(a) = r_{n}(x), \qquad \varphi(x) = 0 $$

Taking derivate of function 8, we get $$ \begin{align} \varphi’(z) = -f’(z) - \Big[\frac{f’’(z)}{1!}(x - z) - f’(z) \Big]

  • \Big[ \frac{f’’’(z)}{2!}(x - z)^{2} - \frac{f’’(z)}{1!}(x - z) \Big] \
  • \cdots - \Big[ \frac{f^{(n + 1)}(z)}{n!}(x - z)^{n} - \frac{f^{(n)}(z)}{(n - 1)!}(x - z)^{(n - 1)} \Big] \end{align} $$

on simplification, we get $$ \varphi’(z) = -\frac{f^{(n + 1)}(z)}{n!}(x - z)^{n} \tag{9} $$

^b19148

suppose there is a function $\psi(z)$ such that it is continuous in the interval $[a, x]$ and has a non-vanishing derivative on in interval $(a, x)$.

By [[../theory-on-differential-functions/Theory on differential functions#^8ade4a|Cauchy theorem]], there must exist $a < c < x$ such that $$ \frac{\varphi(a) - \varphi(x)}{\psi(a) - \psi(x)} = \frac{\varphi’(c)}{\psi’(c)} $$ $$ \frac{\varphi(a) - 0}{\psi(a) - \psi(x)} = \frac{\varphi’(c)}{\psi’(c)} $$ $$ \varphi(a) = \frac{{\psi(a) - \psi(x)}}{\psi’(c)} \varphi’(c) $$

If we choose $\psi(z) = (x - z)^{(n + 1)}$, we have $$\psi(x) = 0, \quad \psi(a) = (x - a)^{n + 1}\quad \psi’(c) = -(n + 1)(x - c)^{n}$$

so, we have $$ \varphi(a) = \frac{(x - a)^{(n + 1)} - 0}{-(n + 1)(x - c)^{n}} \varphi’(c) $$ $$ \varphi(a) = \frac{(x - a)^{(n + 1)}}{-(n + 1)(x - c)^{n}} \varphi’(c) $$ using [[#^b19148 | equation 9]] $$ \varphi(a) = \frac{(x - a)^{(n + 1)}}{-(n + 1)(x - c)^{n}} \Big[ -\frac{f^{(n + 1)}(c)}{n!}(x - c)^{n}\Big] $$ $$ \varphi(a) = r_{n}{x} = \frac{f^{(n + 1)}(c)}{(n + 1)!} (x - a)^{(n + 1)} \tag{10} $$ $$ \begin{align} f(x) = f(a) + \frac{1}{1!} f’(a) (x - a) + \frac{1}{2!} f’’(a) (x - a)^{2} + \cdots + \frac{1}{n!} f^{(n)}(a) (x - a)^{n} \ + \frac{f^{(n + 1)}(c)}{(n + 1)!} (x - a)^{(n + 1)}\tag{11} \end{align} $$ equation $11$ is called Taylor’s formula with the additional term in Lagrange’s form.

Expansion of some common function in Taylor Series

Expansion of $e^{x}$ in Taylor series

Let $f(x) = e^x$. $$ \begin{align} f(x) = e^{x}, \qquad f(0) = 1 \ f’(x) = e^{x}, \qquad f’(0) = 1 \ \vdots \qquad \qquad \qquad \vdots \qquad\ f^{(n)} = e^{x}, \qquad f^{(n)}(0) = 1 \end{align} $$

$$ \begin{align} f(x) = e^{x}= 1 + \frac{x}{1!} + \frac{x^{2}}{2!} + \frac{x^{3}}{3!}+ \cdots + \frac{x^{n}}{n!} + r_{n}x \ r_{n}x = \frac{x^{n + 1}}{(n+1)!}e^c \end{align} $$
